newsitem.title: ZAIRE: Zaire rebels to relaunch offensive, capital jittery.
newsitem.headline: Zaire rebels to relaunch offensive, capital jittery.

text.p: Zaire's rebels said on Sunday they were relaunching their whirlwind offensive after expiry of a three-day deadline for President Mobutu Sese Seko to quit.
The new military governor of Zaire's teeming capital, a declared rebel target, appealed for calm, saying that developments on the war front had sown panic in the city.
On the humanitarian front, relief officials announced a cholera epidemic among Rwandan Hutu refugees in the rebel-held east, saying it would delay a planned repatriation airlift.
"An atmosphere of panic, due essentially to the situation in the east of our country, reigns among Kinshasa's men and women," General Amela Lokima told state television.
"The most fantastic rumours according to which the city of Kinshasa would soon fall to the armed rebellion are gaining ground," he said in an address during the lunchtime news.
The television announcer said panic had gripped districts of Kinshasa near the airport after anti-Mobutu militants urged residents to evacuate.

Opposition militants who have declared support for rebel leader Laurent Kabila have called for a total shutdown of the capital on Monday as part of a planned campaign to force an end to Mobutu's 32-year rule.
Amela called on Zaireans and foreigners living in the city of five million people to remain calm, adding: "The security of our capital is our fundamental duty."
The rebels, who control half the vast Central African nation, including its mineral-rich economic heartland, said on Sunday they were resuming their offensive.
Bizima Karaha, foreign affairs commissioner in the rebel alliance, told a news conference at their headquarters in the eastern city of Goma that Mobutu had had his last chance.

"We have decided that we will not give Mobutu any more chance... We want them (the government) to go -- and after they have left we will consider a ceasefire because if Mobutu leaves it will be the end of the war," he said.
The rebels have been pushing for a summit between Mobutu and Kabila. Karaha said Kabila would probably go to South Africa soon to spur negotiations on Mobutu's departure.

On Saturday, Mobutu dismissed Kabila's deadline for him to show willingness to quit but left the door ajar for face-to-face talks with Kabila, whose rebels took up arms in October in a dispute over Zairean nationality for ethnic Tutsis.
"If he asks me politely I cannot refuse to talk to a compatriot but (for him) to be in Goma and say I give him three days, it's not my style or nature. I cannot reply," he said.
Mobutu, 66, had prostate cancer surgery in Europe in August. He has accused rivals of taking advantage of his illness.
He declared a nationwide state of emergency on Tuesday, naming Amela among five military governors in areas not under rebel control.
He named General Likulia Bolongo as his emergency rule prime minister on Wednesday, shunting aside his veteran opposition foe Etienne Tshisekedi, who had held the job for less than a week.
With Tshisekedi supporters accusing Mobutu of treason and openly calling for his removal, Likulia said on Saturday that all street protests in Kinshasa were banned.
"The people cannot take to the streets. We are under a state of emergency. Police measures have been taken to curb activities of the political parties," he told reporters.
Thousands of opposition militants trying to move Tshisekedi into the premier's offices clashed with troops on Wednesday.
